page.title: 01Oxwich Penrice and the Marsh
page.content: An incredibly diverse area containing a national nature reserve. A sheltered summer anchorage for small boats. A great expanse of gloden sand with up to 10,000 visitors on a busy bank holiday, which is backed by a fragile and mobile dune system. Behind the dunes, a secret marshland world of open water surrounded by great reed beds with islands of alder and willow. The wood covered slopes of the 200ft limestone plateau hide an ancient church which serves the nearby village. The village slumbers through winter with several empty cottages, empty holiday chalets and empty camping sites. In summer the village population increases fivetold and cars snake across the narrow marsh road. To the north lies the southern slope of the 600ft red sandstone ridge with winter bracken. Streams rising
